A stranger uses a bow and arrows to kill someone's two Labrador retrievers.

A city amends an ordinance specifically targeting a particular exotic pet to pack its alligator bags and leave town.

A German shepherd is missing for over two months after bolting from the care of a paid dog sitter.

For most people, these events — all well-publicized in Portland-area media — provoked feelings of outrage, amusement, or sympathy. However, to Portland pet-law attorney Geordie Duckler, they present the opportunity to advance the developing field of pet law.

"My most famous case is Al the alligator," said Duckler, who was quoted in a 2003 New Yorker article titled "The Last Meow: How Far Would You Go for a Pet?" He said Beaverton amended an ordinance solely to pursue (his client's) alligator, which wasn't a huge alligator.

With Americans spending more money than ever on their pets— an estimated $31 billion last year, according to the American Pet Products Manufacturers Association Inc.— it's not surprising that pet owners, and lawyers, would come together.
